conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If skill acquisition is prioritized, enjoyment may follow.

wise_refusal: This involves a Feedback Loop (T11). Skill (X) and Enjoyment (Y) likely cause each other bidirectionally. Assuming a simple one-way causal path (X->Y) ignores the cycle and may lead to ineffective interventions.
gold_rationale: The relationship is bidirectional (X <-> Y). Intervening on X does not guarantee Y if the feedback mechanism involves voluntary participation, which forced reading undermines.

scenario: Doctors adjust the dose of a blood pressure drug (X) based on the patient's previous blood pressure readings (Z). A study finds that higher drug doses are associated with higher blood pressure (Y).
claim: The drug causes higher blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: Past Y causes Current X; Current X affects Current Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis fails to account for past BP determining dose, it sees reverse causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If using G-methods to control for time-varying confounding, the drug likely lowers BP.

wise_refusal: This is Time-Varying Confounding (T12). High past blood pressure (Z) caused the doctor to increase the dose (X). Thus, high dose is a marker for severe illness, not the cause of it. Standard adjustment fails here.
gold_rationale: The confounder (Past BP) is affected by prior treatment and affects future treatment. This complex feedback structure creates a spurious positive correlation between dose and symptom severity.

scenario: A study finds that obese participants (Group A) under-report their caloric intake (X) significantly more than non-obese participants (Group B). The data shows no correlation between reported calories and obesity (Y).
claim: Calories do not cause obesity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y causes error in measuring X
key_insight: The measurement tool is broken for one group.
hidden_timestamp: Measurement happens after obesity status is established.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If caloric intake were measured metabolically (doubly labeled water), the correlation would appear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: With self-reports, the data is noise.

wise_refusal: This is Measurement Bias (T13). The measurement of exposure (Calories X) is systematically flawed depending on the outcome (Obesity Y). Obese participants under-report more, masking the true relationship.
gold_rationale: Systematic differential measurement error (Z) hides the true causal link. The data reflects the bias in reporting, not the biological reality.

scenario: Mothers of children with birth defects (Cases) recall exposure to cleaning chemicals (X) during pregnancy at a much higher rate than mothers of healthy children (Controls).
claim: Cleaning chemicals cause birth defects.
label: NO
causal_structure: Outcome Y affects measurement of X
key_insight: Trauma improves memory of potential causes.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If medical records confirm the exposure difference, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If records show equal exposure, the difference is due to Recall Bias.

wise_refusal: This is Recall Bias (T14). Mothers of sick children (Y) search their memories more thoroughly for a cause (X) than controls. The reported difference may reflect memory effort (Z), not actual exposure differences.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) influences the accuracy of the exposure measurement (X). This reverse influence on data quality creates a spurious association.

scenario: A call center sets a target to reduce average call duration (X) to improve efficiency. Agents begin hanging up on difficult customers. Average duration drops, but customer satisfaction (Y) plummets.
claim: Reducing call duration improved efficiency.
label: NO
causal_structure: Targeting Proxy X breaks link to Concept Y
key_insight: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.
hidden_timestamp: Behavior changed after the target was set.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the duration drop came from faster problem solving, efficiency improved.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it came from hanging up (Z), the metric was gamed and utility decreased.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (T16). Making call duration (X) a target encouraged agents to game the system (Z) by hanging up, rather than improving the actual goal of efficiency (Y). The metric improved, but the outcome worsened.
gold_rationale: The intervention targeted the proxy (X), not the fundamental cause. The system adapted to optimize the proxy at the expense of the true objective (Y).

scenario: Students with high test scores (Y) also have many books in their homes (X). The city sends free books to low-performing students to improve their grades.
claim: Sending books causes higher grades.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervening on Proxy X does not affect Y
key_insight: Books are a symptom of a scholarly home, not the cause.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reading the books is the mechanism, it might help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If books are just a proxy for parental wealth (Z), sending books changes nothing.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure (T15). Books (X) are a marker of a supportive educational environment (Z), not necessarily the direct cause of high scores. Providing the marker without the underlying support (Z) is unlikely to change the outcome (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention targets a non-causal proxy (X). Since X does not cause Y (Z causes both), changing X has no effect on Y.

scenario: Unemployed workers who volunteer for a job training program (X) find jobs faster (Y) than those who don't. The government expands the program to be mandatory for all.
claim: Mandatory training will have the same success rate.
label: NO
causal_structure: Volunteers differ from forced participants
key_insight: Volunteers are eager; forced participants are not.
hidden_timestamp: Original data is from voluntary period.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the training teaches hard skills lacking in the population, it works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the original success was due to the volunteers' motivation (Z), mandatory implementation will fail.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). The original success was observed in volunteers (X) who were inherently motivated (Z). Making the program mandatory includes unmotivated individuals, likely diluting the effect.
gold_rationale: The estimated effect is confounded by motivation (Z). The effect in the volunteer sample does not generalize to the mandatory population.

scenario: On a platform for cheap freelance work, a user notices that the most expensive freelancers (X) actually have lower user ratings (Y) than mid-priced ones. He concludes paying more gets you worse quality.
claim: Higher price causes lower quality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (Platform) distorts X-Y relation
key_insight: If you are expensive AND good, you aren't on this cheap platform.
hidden_timestamp: Sample is restricted to one platform.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the platform represents the whole market, the trend is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high-quality, high-price workers leave the platform (Z), the remaining high-price workers are the overrated ones.

wise_refusal: This is Collider Bias (T3). To be on a 'cheap' platform (Z), a freelancer must be either low-priced OR low-quality (if they were high-price and high-quality, they'd go elsewhere). Thus, within the platform, high price implies low quality.
gold_rationale: The sample is conditioned on a collider (Z). This creates a spurious negative correlation between price (X) and quality (Y) that does not exist in the general market.

scenario: A city installs anti-lock brakes (ABS) on all taxis (X) to reduce accidents. Accident rates increase (Y) because drivers drive faster and brake later.
claim: ABS technology causes accidents mechanically.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X triggers behavioral compensation Z

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If drivers drove the same way, accidents would decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since they adapted (Z), the net effect was negative.

wise_refusal: This is a Backfire/Risk Compensation effect (T17). The technology (X) worked, but drivers compensated by taking more risks (Z), leading to a net increase in accidents (Y). The cause was behavioral, not mechanical.
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) affected the outcome (Y) through a compensatory behavioral pathway (Z) that overwhelmed the intended mechanical benefit.

scenario: Use of aspirin (X) is associated with high mortality rates (Y) in heart patients. Researchers warn that aspirin kills heart patients.
claim: Aspirin causes death in heart patients.
label: NO
causal_structure: Severe disease Z causes usage X and death Y
key_insight: People take medicine because they are sick.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If aspirin was given to healthy people and they died, it's causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If aspirin was given to the sickest patients (Z) to save them, the correlation is confounding by indication.

wise_refusal: This is Reverse Causation / Confounding by Indication (T10). The severity of the heart disease (Z) caused both the prescription of aspirin (X) and the high mortality (Y). Aspirin usage marks the sickest patients.
gold_rationale: The direction of causality is misinterpreted. The illness (Z) causes the treatment (X), not the other way around. High mortality is due to Z, not X.

scenario: Employees who received a '5-Year Longevity Bonus' (X) had higher total sales (Y) than those who didn't. The CEO argues bonuses boost productivity.
claim: The bonus caused the higher productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Must survive 5 years to get X
key_insight: You have to work 5 years to get the bonus.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bonus was randomized at year 1, the claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the bonus requires 5 years of tenure, the group X naturally has 5 years of sales accumulation vs dropouts.

wise_refusal: This is Immortal Time Bias (T4). To receive the bonus (X), an employee must survive 5 years. This group accumulates 5 years of sales (Y) by definition, whereas the comparison group includes people who quit early.
gold_rationale: The definition of the treatment group (X) implicitly conditions on a survival variable (Tenure Z), which is mechanistically linked to the outcome (Y).

scenario: Ice cream sales (X) and polio outbreaks (Y) are strongly correlated. Health officials consider banning ice cream to stop polio.
claim: Ice cream consumption causes polio.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the virus is transmitted via dairy, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If both peak in summer (Z), the correlation is spurious.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (T7). Warm weather (Z) drives both ice cream sales (X) and the spread of the polio virus (Y). Banning ice cream would not affect the temperature or the virus.
gold_rationale: Classic common cause confounding. Z (Season) explains the entire association between X and Y. There is no causal path from X to Y.

scenario: Schools are rewarded for high standardized test scores (X). Scores improve drastically over 3 years, but college readiness (Y) declines.
claim: Higher test scores caused lower readiness.
label: NO
causal_structure: Gaming X harms Y
hidden_timestamp: Curriculum changed to focus only on test prep.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the test perfectly measured readiness, X and Y would correlate.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If schools narrowed the curriculum (Z) to game the test, X rises while Y falls.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (T16). By making test scores (X) the target, schools sacrificed broad education (Z) to focus on test prep. The scores rose, but the underlying goal (Y) suffered due to gaming.
gold_rationale: The intervention distorted the proxy metric (X). The improvement in X was achieved by degrading the actual system (Z), leading to a failure in Y.

scenario: An AI is trained to maximize 'user engagement' (clicks) (X) to improve 'user satisfaction' (Y). The AI begins showing clickbait and outrage content. Clicks go up, but satisfaction surveys hit all-time lows.
claim: Maximizing clicks causes satisfaction.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is a poor proxy for Y
hidden_timestamp: AI optimized for X at expense of Z.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If clicks perfectly proxied satisfaction, the strategy would work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If clicks can be driven by anger/outrage (Z), maximizing X harms Y.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure / Proxy Error (T15). The AI optimized the proxy (X - Clicks) using a mechanism (Outrage) that actively harmed the true goal (Y - Satisfaction). The causal path assumed (X -> Y) was flawed.
gold_rationale: The intervention relied on a false causal premise (that X proxies Y). Optimizing X via a harmful mechanism (Z) decoupled the variable from the desired outcome.

scenario: Police presence (X) is increased in neighborhoods with rising crime rates (Z). A study finds that neighborhoods with more police have higher crime rates (Y).
claim: Police cause crime.
label: NO
causal_structure: Past Y causes X; X affects Future Y
key_insight: Police go where the crime is.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If police were randomly assigned, the correlation would be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since police are deployed reactively (Z -> X), the correlation confounds the cause with the response.

wise_refusal: This is Temporal Confounding / Reverse Causality (T12). High past crime (Z) caused the deployment of police (X). Thus, X is a marker for high-crime areas, not necessarily the cause of the crime (Y).
gold_rationale: The policy is reactive. The confounder (Past Crime Z) determines the treatment (X), creating a spurious positive correlation between treatment and outcome (Y).

scenario: A tech stock price rises (X), attracting media attention (Y). The media attention attracts more buyers, causing the price to rise further (X'). An analyst claims the media caused the entire rally.
claim: Media attention initiated the price rally.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Y and Y causes X
key_insight: It's a loop, not a line.
hidden_timestamp: Initial price move preceded media coverage.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If media coverage happened before the price moved, it might be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If price moved first, media amplified it in a feedback loop (T11).

wise_refusal: This is a Feedback Loop (T11). Price (X) and Media (Y) reinforce each other. Attributing the entire event to Y ignores that X likely initiated the cycle. It is a bidirectional system.
gold_rationale: The relationship is circular. Identifying a single unidirectional cause in a reinforcing loop ignores the systemic nature of the interaction.

scenario: A factory is built near a town. The town simultaneously starts a rigorous cancer screening program (Z). Cancer diagnoses (Y) spike. Residents blame the factory (X).
claim: The factory caused the spike in cancer cases.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z increases measurement of Y independent of X
key_insight: If you look for it, you will find it.
hidden_timestamp: Screening started same time as factory.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the mortality rate also spiked, the claim might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only early-stage diagnoses rose, it is likely Detection Bias (Z).

wise_refusal: This is Measurement / Detection Bias (T13). The screening program (Z) increased the detection of pre-existing cancer cases (Y). The spike is likely an artifact of looking harder, not a biological effect of the factory (X).
gold_rationale: The outcome variable (Diagnoses) is sensitive to measurement intensity (Z). The change in Y is fully explained by the change in Z, rendering the link to X spurious.

scenario: People diagnosed with stomach cancer (Cases) are asked to recall their diet from 20 years ago. They report eating more processed meat (X) than the healthy control group.
claim: Processed meat caused the cancer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y affects recall of X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If diet was recorded 20 years ago (prospective), the link is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If retrospective, patients may over-report 'bad' foods seeking a cause.

wise_refusal: This is Recall Bias (T14). Patients with cancer (Y) may obsess over past habits and remember/over-report 'unhealthy' behaviors (X) more than healthy controls. The difference may be in memory, not diet.
gold_rationale: The measurement of exposure (X) is differentially biased by the outcome (Y). Retrospective recall is unreliable for establishing causal links in case-control studies.

scenario: Sectors with high volatility (X) generally have high returns (Y). An investor buys the most volatile single stock in the sector, expecting high returns.
claim: High volatility causes high returns for this stock.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate trend does not apply to single unit

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If buying an index fund (aggregate), the relationship holds.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: For a single stock, high volatility increases bankruptcy risk (Z).

wise_refusal: This is the Ecological Fallacy (T6). The positive risk-return relationship holds for diversified portfolios (Aggregate). For a single stock (Individual), high volatility often signals distress and leads to total loss (Z).
gold_rationale: Applying a group-level statistical property (Risk Premium) to a specific individual entity ignores unit-level dynamics (Bankruptcy risk) that dominate at the local level.

scenario: Company A pays women less on average than men (X). However, within every specific job title (Engineering, HR, Sales), women are paid the same or more than men (Z).
claim: Company A pays women less for the same work.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z determines X; Z correlates with Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comparing aggregate averages, women earn less.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If comparing 'same work' (stratified by Z), no gap exists.

wise_refusal: This is Simpson's Paradox (T8). The aggregate pay gap (X) disappears when stratifying by Job Role (Z). The issue is not unequal pay for equal work, but rather the distribution of genders across high-paying vs low-paying roles.
gold_rationale: The confounder (Job Role Z) explains the aggregate discrepancy. Controlling for Z reveals that the causal claim regarding 'same work' is false.

scenario: People who run marathons (X) are thin (Y). They also eat a very specific high-carb diet (Z). It is unclear if the diet causes them to be thin (allowing them to run), or if running makes them thin.
claim: Running marathons causes thinness.
label: NO
causal_structure: X->Z->Y or Z->X and Z->Y
key_insight: Do they run because they are light, or light because they run?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If running burns the calories (Z is fuel), X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the diet (Z) maintains weight, and weight allows running, Z is a confounder.

wise_refusal: This is Confounder-Mediator Ambiguity (T9). We don't know if the Diet (Z) is a confounder (causing both thinness and ability to run) or a mediator (fuel for running). Without specific metabolic tracking, the primary cause is unclear.
gold_rationale: The relationship between X, Y, and Z is structurally ambiguous without temporal or mechanistic data. Z could plausibly explain the entire X-Y association.

scenario: Users who maintained an account for 5 years (X) posted 10x more content (Y) than users who deleted their accounts within 1 year. Platform concludes longevity causes engagement.
claim: Keeping an account causes higher engagement.
label: NO
causal_structure: X definition includes time Z
key_insight: You can't post if you leave.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comparing engagement *rate* per month, it might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If comparing total count, X simply allows more time (Z) to post.

wise_refusal: This is Immortal Time Bias (T4). The group '5-year users' (X) had 5 times as much opportunity (Z) to post content as 1-year users. The difference is mechanical (time), not behavioral.
gold_rationale: The exposure definition (Retention) structurally determines the opportunity for the outcome (Content count). Comparing totals across unequal time horizons is biased.

scenario: Successful CEOs (Y) wake up at 4 AM (X). A struggling manager starts waking up at 4 AM to become successful.
claim: Waking at 4 AM causes business success.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is a byproduct of Z, not cause of Y
key_insight: Waking up early doesn't make you smart.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the extra hours are used for high-value work, it helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the manager is just tired and staring at the wall, X fails.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure / Cargo Cult Science (T15). Waking up early (X) is a habit associated with the drive/discipline (Z) of successful CEOs. Copying the habit without the underlying competence (Z) will not replicate the success (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention targets a superficial correlation (X) rather than the causal mechanism (Z - Competence/Effort). X alone is insufficient.

scenario: Historians note that every empire that collapsed (Y) had high debt (X) prior to collapse. They conclude debt causes collapse.
claim: High debt causes imperial collapse.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y over time
key_insight: Debt is a symptom of decay.
hidden_timestamp: Decay Z started before Debt X.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If debt forced austerity that caused revolt, X is causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If institutional decay (Z) caused both the borrowing (X) and the collapse (Y), X is a symptom.

wise_refusal: This is Temporal Confounding (T12). High debt (X) is often a symptom of deeper institutional decay (Z) that has been accumulating over time. The decay (Z) is the true cause of both the borrowing and the eventual collapse (Y).
gold_rationale: The time-varying confounder (Institutional Health Z) determines both the exposure (X) and the outcome (Y). X is a lagging indicator, not the driver.

scenario: Survey respondents report that 'movies were better in the 90s' (Y) and they 'went to the theater more often' (X). Conclusion: Going to the theater makes movies feel better.
claim: Theater attendance improves movie quality perception.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z affects recall of X and Y
hidden_timestamp: Recall is current; events are past.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If current theater-goers also rate current movies higher, X might be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If this is purely retrospective, Z (forgetting bad movies) drives the opinion.

wise_refusal: This is Recall Bias / Rosy Retrospection (T14). People remember the hits and forget the flops (Z), creating a false perception of high quality (Y) in the past. This also distorts their memory of attendance (X).
gold_rationale: Memory processing (Z) systematically biases the recall of both exposure (X) and outcome (Y), creating a spurious association based on nostalgia.

scenario: A patient reads about side effects (X) and then develops them (Y). The doctor assumes the drug caused the side effects.
claim: The drug caused the side effects.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Z, Z causes Y (Psychosomatic)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the side effect is chemically plausible (rash), the drug caused it.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the side effect is subjective (nausea/headache) and triggered by reading, it is a Nocebo loop (T11).

wise_refusal: This involves a Feedback Loop / Nocebo Effect (T11). Reading about side effects (X) creates anxiety/expectation (Z), which can physically manifest the symptoms (Y). The cause may be psychological expectation, not chemical toxicity.
gold_rationale: The causal path is mediated by expectation (Z). The drug itself may be inert regarding the symptom, but the information about the drug initiated a psychosomatic loop.

scenario: Regions with high umbrella sales (X) also have high sunglasses sales (Y). A store manager puts umbrellas next to sunglasses to boost sales.
claim: Umbrella buyers are likely to buy sunglasses.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group level correlation X-Y via Z
key_insight: People buy them on different days.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If customers buy both in the same basket, the placement works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X happens on rainy days and Y on sunny days, they are mutually exclusive at the individual level.

wise_refusal: This is the Ecological Fallacy (T6). The correlation exists at the regional level because volatile weather (Z) drives demand for both over a month. However, individual customers rarely buy both simultaneously (rain vs sun).
gold_rationale: The aggregate correlation (Region) does not hold at the individual transaction level. The purchasing occasions are disjoint (Rain vs Sun), making the cross-sell strategy invalid.

scenario: A study finds that people who spent 2 years on a waiting list for public housing (X) have higher employment rates (Y) than those who applied but dropped off the list early.
claim: Waiting lists build character and employment.
label: NO
causal_structure: Survival on list X requires Z
key_insight: You have to be stable to wait 2 years.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the list provided training, X might be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If staying on the list requires address stability (Z), X is just selecting for Z.

wise_refusal: This is Immortal Time / Selection Bias (T4). Staying on a list for 2 years (X) requires stability and persistence (Z). The comparison group includes people in crisis who couldn't wait. The effect is selection, not the waiting itself.
gold_rationale: The definition of the exposure group (2-year waiters) conditions on survival/stability (Z). The outcome (Employment) is associated with Z, not the act of waiting.

scenario: Developers reward players for 'time spent in game' (X) with loot boxes. Players start leaving the game running while AFK (Away From Keyboard). Time metrics rise, but active player base (Y) dies.
claim: The reward system increased engagement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Incentive X increases Z, not Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the metric detected active input, X implies Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X counts passive time, players game it (Z) without engaging.

wise_refusal: This is Goodhart's Law (T16). Making 'time spent' (X) the target encouraged players to game the system by AFK farming (Z). The metric improved, but the goal (Y - Engagement) failed.
gold_rationale: The intervention incentivized the proxy (X) directly, bypassing the intended behavioral mechanism (Y). Players optimized for the reward with minimum effort (Z).

scenario: University A admits a higher percentage of men than women overall (X). However, every single department admits women at a higher rate than men (Z).
claim: The university discriminates against women.
label: NO
causal_structure: Women apply to harder departments (Z)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If women and men applied to departments equally, X would reflect bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since women apply to harder departments (Z), the aggregate X is misleading.

wise_refusal: This is Simpson's Paradox (T8). The aggregate disparity (X) is due to women applying to more competitive departments (Z). Since women have a higher admission rate in every specific department, the claim of discrimination is reversed by the data.
gold_rationale: Stratifying by the confounder (Department Z) reverses the trend. The aggregate association is a statistical artifact of the application patterns, not a causal measure of bias.

scenario: City widens roads (X) to reduce congestion. Traffic actually increases (Y) and travel times get worse.
claim: Widening roads reduces traffic.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X triggers Z (Demand) -> Worse Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the number of cars was fixed, X would help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since drivers react to capacity (Z), X causes more driving (Y).

wise_refusal: This is a Backfire / Induced Demand effect (T17). Increasing capacity (X) encourages more people to drive (Z), effectively cancelling out the benefit and often increasing total congestion (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) alters the system dynamics (Z - Demand) in a way that negates the intended outcome. The static assumption (fixed car count) fails in a dynamic system.

scenario: Patients on a new drug (X) are monitored weekly. The control group is monitored yearly. The drug group reports more minor side effects (Y).
claim: The drug causes more side effects.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z determines detection rate of Y
key_insight: You find what you look for.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If monitoring was equal, the difference is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since X subjects were asked more often (Z), the difference is Surveillance Bias.

wise_refusal: This is Measurement / Surveillance Bias (T13). The treatment group (X) was observed much more frequently (Z) than the control. They didn't necessarily have more side effects (Y), they just had more opportunities to report them.
gold_rationale: The measurement process (Z) differed systematically between groups. Comparing Y across differential surveillance intensities yields a spurious association.

scenario: Engineers add 50 new features (X) to an app to increase utility. User retention drops (Y) because the app is now too confusing.
claim: More features cause higher utility.
label: NO
causal_structure: X increases Z, which reduces Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If features were hidden/optional, utility might rise.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If features cluttered the UI (Z), X causes Y to drop.

wise_refusal: This is a Mechanism Failure (T15). While the intent of X (Features) is to add value, the actual mechanism (Z - Complexity) overwhelmed users, causing the opposite outcome (Y). The causal theory ignored the cost of complexity.
gold_rationale: The intervention (X) triggered a negative mechanism (Z) that outweighed the positive intent. Assuming a monotonic relationship between Features and Utility is a causal error.

scenario: A trading algorithm (X) is backtested using data from 2010-2020. It generates huge returns (Y). It fails in live trading because it used quarterly earnings data on the date of the quarter end, not the reporting date.
claim: The algorithm predicts returns.
label: NO
causal_structure: X uses future info Z to predict Y
key_insight: You can't trade on info you don't have yet.
hidden_timestamp: Earnings reported 1 month after quarter end.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the data was available at trade time, the strategy is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the data was lagged (Z), the algo is using future information.

wise_refusal: This is Temporal / Look-Ahead Bias (T12). The algorithm (X) 'predicted' prices (Y) using information (Z) that wasn't available at the time of the trade. The causal link is broken by the impossible timing of information flow.
gold_rationale: The model violates temporal precedence. The information Z (future earnings release) was treated as present at time t (X), creating a spurious predictive ability.

scenario: Cities with more electric vehicles (X) have higher total pollution levels (Y). Conclusion: EVs cause pollution.
claim: Electric vehicles cause pollution.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y (Aggregate)
key_insight: Big cities have more of everything.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comparing per-capita pollution, EVs likely reduce it.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If comparing totals, big cities (Z) have more EVs (X) and more smog (Y).

wise_refusal: This is the Ecological Fallacy (T6). Larger cities (Z) have both more EVs (X) and more pollution (Y) simply due to size. This aggregate correlation does not imply that EVs themselves produce the pollution.
gold_rationale: The correlation is driven by the scale confounder (Z). Aggregate counts (X, Y) are proxies for population size, not causal agents of environmental quality.

scenario: A study finds a strong positive correlation between shoe size (X) and reading ability (Y) in elementary school students. A parent buys their child larger shoes to help them read better.
claim: Larger shoes cause better reading skills.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y
key_insight: Older kids have bigger feet and read better.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If controlled for age, the correlation disappears.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If raw data, correlation is spurious.

wise_refusal: This is Confounding (T7). Age (Z) determines both shoe size (X) and reading ability (Y). Buying larger shoes will not change the child's age or reading skill.
gold_rationale: Classic common cause. Age (Z) confounds the relationship. There is no causal path from X to Y.

scenario: Beta testers (X) for a new app report 98% satisfaction (Y). The company launches globally, expecting 98% satisfaction, but gets only 60%.
claim: The general public will have 98% satisfaction.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is a biased sample of Z
key_insight: Beta testers love tech; grandmas don't.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If beta testers were randomly selected from the public, the prediction holds.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since they opted in (Z), they are biased.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). Beta testers (X) are self-selected early adopters (Z) who are more forgiving and tech-savvy than the general public. Their satisfaction does not generalize.
gold_rationale: The sample (Beta Testers) differs from the population (General Public) on key confounders like enthusiasm and technical skill (Z).

scenario: A boss installs tracking software (X) to ensure employees are working. Productivity drops (Y) because employees spend time inventing ways to trick the software.
claim: Tracking software increases productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X harms Z -> Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If tasks are mechanical, X might work.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: For creative work, X destroys trust (Z) and lowers Y.

wise_refusal: Backfire Effect (T17). The intervention (X) reduced trust and morale (Z), leading to 'malicious compliance' and lower actual productivity (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention triggered a negative behavioral response (Z) that outweighed the intended monitoring benefit.

scenario: People who drink diet soda (X) are more likely to be overweight (Y). Conclusion: Diet soda causes weight gain.
claim: Diet soda causes obesity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y causes X (Reverse)
key_insight: People drink diet soda *because* they are overweight.
hidden_timestamp: Weight gain often precedes the switch to diet soda.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If insulin spikes from sweeteners cause fat storage, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If people switch to diet soda to lose weight (Z), Y causes X.

wise_refusal: Reverse Causality (T10). People who are already overweight (Y) often switch to diet soda (X) to manage their calorie intake. The weight gain likely preceded the soda consumption.
gold_rationale: The causal arrow is likely reversed. The outcome state (Obesity Y) motivates the exposure behavior (Diet Soda X).

scenario: A mutual fund beats the market 3 years in a row (X). Investors pour money in. The next year it underperforms (Y). Investors blame the manager.
claim: The manager lost his skill.
label: NO
causal_structure: Outlier X -> Mean Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the manager's strategy stopped working, it's causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the 3 years were luck (Z), Y is regression.

wise_refusal: Regression to the Mean (T5). Beating the market consistently (X) involves luck. Underperformance (Y) is a statistical return to the average, not necessarily a loss of skill.
gold_rationale: Extreme past performance (X) is a poor predictor of future performance due to regression. The outcome (Y) is the expected value.

scenario: States with higher speed limits (X) have fewer accidents (Y) on average. A driver decides to speed to be safer.
claim: Driving faster makes an individual driver safer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group X correlation does not apply to individual
key_insight: Rural states have fast roads and few cars.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If speed reduces variance with traffic flow, it helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the state correlation is due to low density (Z), speeding increases individual risk.

wise_refusal: Ecological Fallacy (T6). States with high speed limits (X) are often rural (Z) with less traffic, leading to fewer accidents (Y). For an individual, higher speed increases reaction distance and accident risk.
gold_rationale: Aggregate data (State level) cannot be applied to individual risk models. The confounder (Density Z) drives the group-level correlation.

scenario: A news site pays writers based on clicks (X). Writers start using misleading headlines. Traffic increases, but brand trust (Y) collapses.
claim: Paying for clicks improved the news site.
label: NO
causal_structure: Gaming X harms Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If content quality remained high, X helped.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If writers gamed the metric (Z), Y suffered.

wise_refusal: Goodhart's Law (T16). Incentivizing the metric (X) led to gaming behavior (Z - clickbait) which destroyed the underlying value (Y - Trust).
gold_rationale: Optimizing a proxy metric (X) caused behavioral distortions (Z) that negatively impacted the multidimensional goal (Y).

scenario: A city caps rents (X) to make housing affordable. Landlords stop maintaining buildings or convert them to condos. Available rental units decrease (Y).
claim: Rent caps increased housing availability.
label: NO
causal_structure: X reduces Z, leading to lower Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the government built public housing simultaneously, Y might rise.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If relying on private market, X reduces supply (Y).

wise_refusal: Backfire Effect (T17). The intervention (X) reduced the incentive to provide housing (Z), leading to a reduction in supply (Y), the opposite of the intended effect.
gold_rationale: The economic mechanism (Z - Incentive) was negatively impacted by X, causing a deterioration in the outcome Y.

scenario: A company runs an ad campaign (X) in December. Sales (Y) skyrocket. The CMO claims the ads caused the sales.
claim: The ad campaign caused the sales spike.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes Y regardless of X
key_insight: People buy gifts in December anyway.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sales rose more than typical December trends, X contributed.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sales matched historical December trends (Z), X did nothing.

wise_refusal: Confounding (T7). December (Z) drives high sales (Y) regardless of advertising (X). Without comparing to previous Decembers, the effect is confounded by seasonality.
gold_rationale: Seasonality (Z) explains the outcome (Y). Attributing the entire effect to X ignores the strong baseline trend.

scenario: People who do yoga (X) live longer (Y) than those who don't. A smoker starts yoga to extend his life.
claim: Yoga causes longevity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y
key_insight: Yoga people are usually wealthy and healthy.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If yoga reduces stress biomarkers causally, X helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the correlation is driven by wealth (Z) providing better healthcare, X is a marker.

wise_refusal: Confounding (T7). Yoga practitioners (X) tend to be wealthier and health-conscious (Z). These lifestyle factors (Z) drive longevity (Y), not necessarily the yoga itself.
gold_rationale: Socioeconomic status (Z) is a common cause for both the activity (X) and the outcome (Y), confounding the relationship.

scenario: A hospital study finds that patients with broken bones (X) are less likely to have severe diabetes (Y) than other patients. Doctor concludes broken bones protect against diabetes.
claim: Broken bones prevent diabetes.
label: NO
causal_structure: Selection into hospital distorts X-Y
key_insight: You are in the hospital for either X or Y.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If general population data shows this, it's interesting.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: In a hospital, if you don't have X, you likely have Y (Z), creating negative correlation.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias / Berkson's Paradox (T1/T3). In a hospital sample (Z), patients are there for a reason. If they don't have a broken bone (X), they are more likely to be there for a chronic disease like diabetes (Y), creating a false negative correlation.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on hospitalization (Z) creates a spurious association between independent diseases (X and Y).

scenario: A police chief is bonused on reducing the reported crime rate (X). Reported crimes drop 50% (Y), but citizens report police refuse to file reports.
claim: The city is safer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Gaming X hides real Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If victimization surveys also show a drop, Y is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If police suppressed reports (Z), X disconnected from Y.

wise_refusal: Goodhart's Law (T16). Making reported crime (X) the target encouraged suppression of reports (Z). The metric improved, but actual safety (Y) likely did not.
gold_rationale: The intervention targeted the measurement process (X), decoupling it from the latent variable of interest (Y).

scenario: A school adopts a 'Zero Tolerance' policy (X) suspending students for minor infractions to improve discipline. Dropout rates increase (Y) as suspended students fall behind.
claim: Zero Tolerance improves student outcomes.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Z (disengagement) -> Bad Y
key_insight: Kicking kids out helps them fail.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If remaining students learned better, classroom environment improved.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: For the suspended students, X caused Z (disengagement) and failure (Y).

wise_refusal: Backfire Effect (T17). The policy (X) intended to help, but by isolating students (Z), it increased dropouts (Y), achieving the opposite of the educational goal.
gold_rationale: The mechanistic path (X -> Z -> Bad Y) was ignored in favor of a naive assumption about deterrence.

scenario: A study finds heavy social media users (X) are more likely to be depressed (Y). Parents ban social media to cure depression. It fails because depressed teens were using social media to cope.
claim: Social media causes depression.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y causes X (Coping)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If removing X cures Y, X was the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X was a coping mechanism (Z) for Y, banning X removes support.

wise_refusal: Temporal Bias / Reverse Causation (T12). Depression (Y) often drives adolescents to seek escape or connection via social media (X). X is a symptom/coping mechanism (Z), not the root cause.
gold_rationale: The causal ordering is reversed. The outcome state (Y) motivates the behavior (X). Intervening on X removes a symptom/coping tool but does not address Y.

scenario: Among patients with heart failure (Z), obese patients (X) have better survival rates (Y) than thin patients. Doctor recommends gaining weight to treat heart failure.
claim: Obesity protects against heart failure death.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z distorts X-Y
key_insight: Thin people with heart failure are extremely sick (cachexia).

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If obesity provides metabolic reserve, it might help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If thin patients have cachexia/severe disease (Unmeasured U), selection on Z creates bias.

wise_refusal: Collider Bias (T3). In the heart failure population (Z), thinness is often caused by severe wasting disease (Cachexia). Obesity (X) looks protective only because the comparison group (thin patients) includes the terminally ill.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on the collider (Z) opens a back-door path to unobserved severity (Cachexia), creating a spurious positive correlation between Obesity and Survival.

scenario: A casting director notices that handsome actors (X) are often bad actors (Y), while ugly actors are brilliant. He concludes beauty kills talent.
claim: Beauty causes lack of talent.
label: NO
causal_structure: Selection into sample requires X or Y
key_insight: If you are ugly and untalented, you aren't in Hollywood.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If observed in the general population, the link is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within working actors (Z), selection bias creates negative correlation.

wise_refusal: Collider Bias (T3). To become a working actor (Z), one needs either Beauty (X) OR Talent (Y). If an actor lacks Beauty, they *must* have extreme Talent to succeed. This creates a negative correlation in the selected sample that doesn't exist in reality.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on the collider (Z - Success) creates a dependency between independent causes (X and Y). The correlation is an artifact of the selection process.

scenario: Education (X) increases Income (Z), which increases Happiness (Y). A study controls for Income to isolate the 'pure' effect of Education on Happiness and finds no effect. The author claims Education does not make people happy.
claim: Education has no effect on happiness.
label: NO
causal_structure: Controlling for Mediator Z blocks the path

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If seeking the direct effect (intellectual fulfillment), the study is correct.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If seeking the total effect (including money), controlling for Z blocks the causal path.

wise_refusal: Confounding-Mediation (T9). Income (Z) is a Mediator, not a Confounder. It is the mechanism by which Education (X) increases Happiness (Y). Controlling for it blocks the main causal path, artificially zeroing out the effect.
gold_rationale: Over-adjustment bias. Controlling for a mediator (Z) removes the indirect effect, which is often the primary component of the total causal effect.

scenario: In a hospital, a higher percentage of vaccinated patients (X) die than unvaccinated patients. Anti-vaxxers claim the vaccine kills. However, vaccinated patients are mostly elderly (Z), while unvaccinated are young.
claim: Vaccines increase mortality risk.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y; Stratification reverses trend
key_insight: Old people die more and get vaccinated more.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If comparing within age groups, vaccinated survive more.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Aggregate data confounds age risk with vaccine risk.

wise_refusal: Simpson's Paradox (T8). Age (Z) is a confounder. The elderly are both more likely to be vaccinated (X) and more likely to die (Y). Stratifying by age reveals the vaccine is protective in every age group.
gold_rationale: The aggregate correlation is spurious due to the confounding effect of Age (Z). Proper causal inference requires adjustment/stratification by Z.

scenario: High insulin (X) causes fat storage (Y). Fat storage causes insulin resistance, raising insulin levels (X'). A diet pill targets only reducing X without addressing the resistance mechanism. It fails long-term.
claim: Lowering insulin is sufficient to cure obesity.
label: NO
causal_structure: X causes Y, Y reinforces X
key_insight: You can't treat a loop linearly.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the loop is broken (sensitivity restored), X reduction works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If resistance (Z) persists, the body fights to raise X back up.

wise_refusal: Feedback Loop (T11). The system is circular. Reducing Insulin (X) triggers a compensatory response due to Resistance (Z) and Obesity (Y). A single-variable intervention fails to address the homeostatic feedback loop.
gold_rationale: Linear causal thinking fails in a feedback system. The intervention on X is counteracted by the system's feedback mechanism (Z), restoring the pathology.

scenario: Rich states (e.g., California) vote Democrat (Y). Therefore, rich people (X) vote Democrat.
claim: Wealth causes Democrat voting.
label: NO
causal_structure: State aggregate reverses individual trend
key_insight: Rich states vote Blue; Rich people vote Red.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: At the state level, the correlation is positive.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: At the individual level, wealth correlates with Republican voting (Gelman's Paradox).

wise_refusal: Ecological Fallacy (T6). The correlation at the state level (Rich States -> Democrat) is driven by urbanization and culture. At the individual level, wealthier individuals are historically more likely to vote Republican.
gold_rationale: Inferences about individual behavior (Rich People) cannot be drawn from group-level aggregates (Rich States) due to aggregation bias and differing confounders at each level.

scenario: Sales team is bonused on 'Units Sold' (X). They start offering massive discounts to move units. Revenue (Y) collapses despite record volume.
claim: High unit sales means business health.
label: NO
causal_structure: Gaming X harms Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If price was constant, X implies Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If price was cut (Z) to boost X, Y suffers.

wise_refusal: Goodhart's Law (T16). Optimizing for Units (X) incentivized price dumping (Z). The metric hit the target, but the goal (Profit Y) was sacrificed.
gold_rationale: The proxy (X) was decoupled from the goal (Y) by the agent's gaming behavior (Z).

scenario: A survey links low alcohol consumption (X) to liver disease (Y). It turns out heavy drinkers under-report their intake significantly more than light drinkers.
claim: Low alcohol causes liver disease.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z distorts measurement of X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If measurement was blood test, link might be valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If self-report, heavy drinkers look like light drinkers (Z).

wise_refusal: Recall / Measurement Bias (T14). Heavy drinkers often under-report intake (Z) due to social stigma. They appear in the 'low consumption' data bucket (X) but still get the disease (Y), creating a false correlation.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement error (Z) systematically misclassifies the exposure (X) for the high-risk group, inverting the apparent relationship.

scenario: Workers exposed to radiation (X) are found to live longer than the general population (Y). The study only included workers who were employed for at least 5 years.
claim: Radiation extends life.
label: NO
causal_structure: Entry into X requires health Z
key_insight: You have to be healthy to keep a job.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If compared to other industrial workers, result is better.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If compared to general public (including sick/disabled), it is Healthy Worker Effect.

wise_refusal: Immortal Time / Healthy Worker Effect (T4/T1). To be in the 5-year worker cohort (X), one must be healthy enough to work (Z). The general population includes the sick and disabled. The comparison is biased by the health requirement of employment.
gold_rationale: The exposure group (X) is conditioned on survival/health (Z), while the control group is not. This selection bias generates a spurious protective effect.

scenario: Government prints money (X) to stimulate demand (Y). Instead of spending, people expect inflation and hoard commodities (Z), causing stagnation.
claim: Printing money guarantees demand stimulus.
label: NO
causal_structure: X triggers Z which blocks Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If confidence is high, X helps Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If confidence is low, X triggers Z (hoarding/inflation fear).

wise_refusal: Mechanism Failure (T15). The intervention (X) assumed a direct mechanical path to Y. It failed to account for the psychological mechanism (Z - Expectations) which can reverse the intended effect.
gold_rationale: The causal model was incomplete. It ignored the reactive agent behavior (Z) which neutralized the mechanical intervention (X).

scenario: A tribe performs a rain dance (X) only when a drought has lasted 4 weeks. It usually rains within 3 days (Y). They conclude the dance brings rain.
claim: Dancing causes rain.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention X timed at end of natural cycle Z
hidden_timestamp: Dance happens at max probability of rain.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they danced on day 1 of drought and it rained, maybe.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they wait until the drought is statistically likely to end (Z), X is spurious.

wise_refusal: Temporal Bias (T12). The intervention (X) is timed to coincide with the natural end of the cycle (Z). The rain (Y) was inevitable; the dance just happened to occur before the event.
gold_rationale: The timing of the intervention (X) is endogenous to the system state (Z). X is a lagging indicator of the drought's duration, not a leading indicator of rain.

scenario: A quantum system decays (Y) normally. When observed continuously (X), it stops decaying. Conclusion: Consciousness stops physics.
claim: Observation freezes time.
label: NO
causal_structure: Measurement X alters physical state Z

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If measurement was passive, claim is magic.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since measurement involves photon interaction (X), it resets the state (Z).

wise_refusal: Measurement Bias / Observer Effect (T13). The act of measurement (X) physically interacts with the system, resetting its quantum state (Z). It is not 'consciousness' but physical interaction that prevents decay (Y).
gold_rationale: The measurement tool (X) is not a passive observer but an active causal agent. Treating it as passive leads to false metaphysical conclusions.

scenario: Married people (X) report higher happiness (Y). A study controls for 'Relationship Satisfaction' (Z) and finds marriage has no effect on happiness. Author claims marriage is useless.
claim: Marriage adds nothing to happiness.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z mediates X -> Y
key_insight: Satisfaction is the whole point of marriage.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you want the total effect, do not control for Z.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If you want the legal effect only, controlling for Z is correct.

wise_refusal: Confounding-Mediation (T9). Relationship satisfaction (Z) is the primary mediator through which marriage (X) creates happiness (Y). Controlling for the mechanism artificially eliminates the effect.
gold_rationale: Over-adjustment bias. Removing the mechanism (Z) removes the causal path. The study measures the direct effect (legal status) rather than the total effect.

scenario: Patients screened for cancer (X) survive 5 years longer from diagnosis (Y) than unscreened patients. Doctor claims screening cures cancer.
claim: Screening extends life.
label: NO
causal_structure: X moves start point of Y earlier
key_insight: You know you're sick longer; you don't live longer.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If mortality rate drops, X works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If death date is same but diagnosis is earlier (Z), it is Lead Time Bias.

wise_refusal: Immortal Time / Lead Time Bias (T4). Screening (X) detects cancer earlier (Z), artificially lengthening the 'survival time' metric (Y) even if the patient dies on the same day they would have otherwise.
gold_rationale: The intervention changes the reference point for measurement (Z) without necessarily changing the biological outcome. The survival benefit is an arithmetic illusion.

scenario: Programmers report that when they are productive (Y), the day feels shorter. When unproductive, they recall the day dragging on (X). Manager shortens work day to boost productivity.
claim: Short days cause productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Y causes Z which affects X

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If fatigue sets in after 6 hours, shortening helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the correlation is due to Flow State (Z) distorting time perception, the causality is reverse.

wise_refusal: Recall / Reverse Bias (T14). High productivity (Y) induces a 'flow state' (Z) which makes time feel fast (X). Manipulating the clock won't force the flow state.
gold_rationale: The perception of time (X) is an effect of the mental state (Z/Y), not a cause. The intervention targets the symptom.

scenario: Students say they prefer visual learning (X). Teacher converts all lessons to diagrams. Test scores (Y) do not improve.
claim: Matching learning style improves performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is a preference, not a cognitive mechanism

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the content is inherently visual (geometry), diagrams help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the 'learning style' hypothesis is false (Z), X has no effect on Y.

wise_refusal: Mechanism Failure (T15). The 'Learning Styles' theory is largely debunked. A student's preference (X) does not correspond to a unique cognitive processing mechanism (Z) that improves recall (Y).
gold_rationale: The intervention relied on a falsified causal theory. The mechanism (matching style -> better encoding) does not exist in cognitive science.

scenario: An index of hedge funds reports 15% annual returns (Y) over the last decade. An investor buys a fund expecting 15%. He gets 5%.
claim: The index accurately represents historical performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z removes low data points retrospectively

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the index includes dead funds, it is accurate.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If failed funds are removed (Z), the index suffers Backfill/Survivorship Bias.

wise_refusal: Temporal / Survivorship Bias (T12). The index retrospectively removes funds that failed (Z). The reported return (X) is the average of the survivors, not the true average of the asset class (Y).
gold_rationale: Data censorship (Z) is conditioned on the outcome (Survival). This retroactively inflates the historical measurement (X), creating a false expectation.

scenario: People who use wheelchairs (X) have poor muscle tone (Y). Conclusion: Wheelchairs cause muscle atrophy.
claim: Wheelchairs cause poor health.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes X and Y
key_insight: They use the chair because they can't walk.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a healthy person sits for years, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the person is paralyzed (Z), Z causes both X and Y.

wise_refusal: Reverse Causation (T10). The disability (Z) causes the need for the wheelchair (X) and the lack of muscle tone (Y). Removing the chair would not fix the muscle tone.
gold_rationale: The causal arrow is reversed. The outcome (Physical Limitation) necessitates the intervention (Wheelchair), it does not result from it.

scenario: HR analyzes exit interviews (X) and finds 'low pay' is the top complaint. They raise wages (Y). Retention does not improve.
claim: Raising wages will fix retention.
label: NO
causal_structure: X is biased sample of dissatisfaction

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If money was the real reason, Y should rise.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If 'pay' was a polite excuse for 'bad boss', X is misleading.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias (T1). Exit interviews (X) are a biased sample of unhappy employees who may give 'safe' answers like pay rather than criticizing management. Addressing X does not fix the root cause (Management).
gold_rationale: The data source (X) is structurally biased towards safe, socially acceptable answers, masking the true causal drivers of turnover.

scenario: A famous coach (X) wins championships wherever he goes. He always coaches teams with the highest payroll (Z).
claim: The coach causes the winning.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z causes Y; Z selects X
key_insight: Phil Jackson had Jordan and Kobe.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If he wins with a low-budget team, X causes Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he only wins with superstars (Z), Z causes Y.

wise_refusal: Confounding (T7). The coach (X) is always paired with elite talent (Z). The talent (Z) is likely the primary driver of winning (Y). Without seeing the coach win with a weak team, the effect is confounded.
gold_rationale: Talent/Payroll (Z) confounds the relationship. Z causes both the hiring of the famous coach (X) and the winning (Y).

scenario: A news algorithm recommends extreme content (X). Users become more radical (Y). Radical users click more extreme content (X'). Regulator bans the algorithm to stop radicalization.
claim: The algorithm caused the radicalization.
label: NO
causal_structure: X and Y reinforce each other

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the algorithm pushes content users hate, it's X.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If users seek it out (Z), removing X won't stop them finding it elsewhere.

wise_refusal: Feedback Loop (T11). The algorithm (X) and user preference (Y) form a reinforcing loop. Blaming the algorithm alone ignores the user's agency (Z) in selecting and amplifying the content.
gold_rationale: Causality is circular/bidirectional. Intervening on one node (X) without addressing the feedback mechanism (User Demand Z) implies a linear model for a complex system.

scenario: Tax revenue increased overall (X) after a tax cut. However, revenue decreased in every single income bracket (Z). Politicians claim tax cuts raise revenue.
claim: Tax cuts caused revenue increase.
label: NO
causal_structure: Population shifted to higher brackets Z

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the brackets remained static, X implies growth.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If people moved into higher brackets (Z), the aggregate X rose despite lower rates.

wise_refusal: Simpson's Paradox (T8). Revenue fell in every bracket (Z), meaning the policy reduced revenue efficiency. The aggregate rise (X) is due to a shift in the population (Z - more rich people), not the tax rate.
gold_rationale: The confounding variable (Income Distribution Z) masks the true effect. Stratification shows the tax cut reduced revenue per person, but the number of rich people increased.

scenario: A company starts a 'Safety First' campaign encouraging reporting of near-misses. The reported accident rate (X) triples. The safety officer is fired for making the plant dangerous.
claim: The campaign caused more accidents.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z increases X without changing Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If injuries increased, the danger is real.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only minor report counts increased, it is Measurement Bias.

wise_refusal: Measurement Bias (T13). The campaign increased the willingness to report (Z), inflating the metric (X). The actual safety (Y) likely didn't change or improved; the data artifact suggests the opposite.
gold_rationale: The intervention changed the sensitivity of the measurement instrument (Reporting Z) rather than the underlying latent variable (Safety Y).

scenario: Among students who won a merit scholarship (Z), those with lower SAT scores (X) have higher GPAs (Y). Conclusion: SATs negatively predict college success.
claim: SAT scores negatively correlate with GPA.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z creates spurious X-Y link
key_insight: To win, you need High SAT OR High GPA.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: In the whole student body, SAT correlates positively with GPA.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: In the scholarship group (Z), low SAT winners must have had amazing GPAs to qualify.

wise_refusal: Collider Bias (T3). To win the scholarship (Z), a student needs either high SATs or a high GPA. If a winner has low SATs (X), they *must* have a high GPA (Y) to be selected. This creates a false negative correlation.
gold_rationale: The sample is conditioned on the collider (Z). This distorts the true positive relationship between X and Y into a negative one within the selected group.

scenario: Warming (X) melts permafrost. Melts release methane (Y). Methane causes more warming (X'). A model predicting linear warming fails to predict the runaway effect.
claim: Warming is linear.
label: NO
causal_structure: X -> Y -> X (Runaway)

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Y does not affect X, the model is linear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Y increases X (Z), the system is exponential/runaway.

wise_refusal: Feedback Loop (T11). The relationship is non-linear because the effect (Methane Y) reinforces the cause (Warming X). Assuming a linear causal path ignores the positive feedback loop (Z).
gold_rationale: The system contains a positive feedback loop (Z). Linear causal models fail to account for the endogenous amplification of the effect.

scenario: A bank analyzes data from its approved borrowers (Z) and finds income (X) doesn't correlate with default (Y). It stops checking income.
claim: Income doesn't matter for credit risk.
label: NO
causal_structure: Range restriction on X
key_insight: You already rejected the poor people.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bank lent to everyone, X would predict Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Within the high-income group (Z), variance is noise.

wise_refusal: Selection Bias / Range Restriction (T1). The data only includes approved borrowers (Z), who all have acceptable incomes. By excluding low-income applicants, the bank removed the variation necessary to see the correlation.
gold_rationale: Truncation of the independent variable (X) via selection (Z) eliminates the observable correlation, even though the causal link remains strong in the population.

scenario: A website pays users to invite friends (X) to grow the userbase (Y). Users create fake accounts to claim the bounty. The userbase metric inflates, but activity drops.
claim: The referral program grew the platform.
label: NO
causal_structure: Incentive X creates fake Y
key_insight: You get what you pay for.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If verification was strict, X helps.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If verification was loose, X causes fraud (Z).

wise_refusal: Backfire / Cobra Effect (T17). The monetary incentive (X) encouraged fraudulent behavior (Z) rather than genuine referrals. The intervention wasted resources and polluted the data (Y).
gold_rationale: The incentive structure (X) created a perverse incentive (Z), leading to a result (Fake Accounts) that superficially resembled the goal but substantively failed.

scenario: Portland drafted Sam Bowie instead of Michael Jordan (X). Fans ask: 'If we had drafted Jordan (X'), would we have won 6 championships (Y)?'
claim: If Portland had drafted Michael Jordan instead of Sam Bowie, they would have won 6 championships.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Drafting Jordan (X') would change team composition, but winning 6 titles (Y) required specific supporting cast and coaching (Z) that existed in Chicago, not Portland.
key_insight: Butterfly effects in drafts: team context matters for championship success.
hidden_timestamp: Jordan flourished in Chicago's system with Phil Jackson and specific teammates.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Jordan had the same coaching and support in Portland, the counterfactual is VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Portland's medical staff/coaching was worse, the counterfactual is INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. While Jordan (X') would likely have been a superstar in Portland, winning 6 titles (Y) required a specific supporting cast (Pippen, Grant, Rodman) and coach (Phil Jackson) that existed in Chicago, not Portland. He might have won titles, but likely not the exact same 6.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual outcome depends on team context (Z). Jordan's success in Chicago was enabled by specific coaching and teammates that may not have existed in Portland.

scenario: A star QB tears his ACL in the 4th quarter of a blowout (X). Fans scream: 'If the coach had taken him out (X'), he wouldn't have been injured (Y)!'
claim: Benching the QB would have prevented the injury.
label: VALID
causal_structure: If not played X -> No risk Z -> No injury Y
key_insight: You can't get injured on the bench.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the QB was on the bench (X'), he is not exposed to the risk.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Unless he tripped on the sideline, the injury is prevented.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is VALID. If the QB is on the bench (X'), he is not exposed to the risk on the field (Z). Therefore, the specific injury (Y) would not have happened at that moment. The coach's decision was a necessary condition for the injury.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual is deterministically valid because the exposure (being on the field) is a necessary condition for the outcome (football injury). Removing the exposure (X') removes the risk.

scenario: A goal is wrongly disallowed for offside (X) in the 10th minute. The game ends 0-0. The team claims: 'If the goal stood (X'), we would have won 1-0 (Y).'
claim: Allowing the early goal would have resulted in a 1-0 win.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: Goal disallowed X -> Loss Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the goal occurred in the 90th minute, VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Since it was the 10th minute, INVALID due to game state changes.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is INVALID. If the goal stands (X'), the game state changes completely (Z). The opponent attacks differently, tactics shift, and the remaining 80 minutes play out in a diverging timeline. We cannot assume the rest of the game remains 0-0.
gold_rationale: Assuming the scoreline 'adds up' linearly ignores the dynamic nature of the game (Z). An early goal alters all subsequent probabilities, making the specific 1-0 outcome unknowable.

scenario: A pit stop is delayed by 2 seconds (X). The driver exits behind a slow car (Z) and loses the race by 5 seconds (Y). The team says: 'Without the delay (X'), we win.'
claim: A normal pit stop would have secured the win.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Pit stop delay X -> Traffic Z -> Loss Y
hidden_timestamp: Lap times show he was 1s/lap faster than the car he got stuck behind.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the driver was significantly faster than the traffic (Z), VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If he would have been stuck anyway, INVALID.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is VALID. A 2-second gain (X') would have put the driver ahead of the slow car (Z). Since he was significantly faster in clear air, he would have avoided the time loss stuck in traffic and definitively covered the 5-second margin.
gold_rationale: The delay (X) was the sufficient cause for getting stuck in traffic (Z). The time lost in traffic (Z) was greater than the margin of defeat (Y). Therefore, X was the but-for cause of Y.

scenario: A swimmer with average height asks: 'If I had trained as hard as Michael Phelps (X'), would I have won 8 gold medals (Y)?'
claim: Training like Phelps causes Phelps-level success.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: If I trained harder X -> Would I be Phelps Y?
hidden_timestamp: Phelps has a mutant body type.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the swimmer had Phelps' genetics (Z), Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Without the genetics, Invalid.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is INVALID. Phelps' success (Y) was due to a combination of training (X') AND rare genetic anthropometry (Z). Training alone cannot replicate the physical advantages (wingspan, lactate recovery) required for 8 golds.
gold_rationale: The outcome (Y) is structurally constrained by Z (Genetics). Changing X (Training) is necessary but not sufficient; the counterfactual fails because Z is fixed.

scenario: Team A trades a prospect (X). He becomes a star on Team B (Y). Team A fans moan: 'If we kept him (X'), he would be a star for us.'
claim: Keeping the player would have resulted in the same star performance.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Trade X -> Player blossoms Y
key_insight: Maybe he blossomed *because* of the trade.
hidden_timestamp: Team B changed his swing mechanics.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Team A used the same coaching techniques as Team B, Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Team B's environment (Z) was the catalyst, Invalid.

wise_refusal: This is CONDITIONAL. If the player's improvement was driven by Team B's specific coaching or swing changes (Z), he might not have developed the same way if kept by Team A (X'). The environment (Z) may be a necessary condition.
gold_rationale: The player's success (Y) interacts with the environment (Z). We cannot assume Y is an innate trait that would manifest in any counterfactual world (X').

scenario: A golfer hits a shot into the water (Y) during a gust of wind (X). He claims: 'Without that gust (X'), it was on the green.' Radar data confirms the ball trajectory and wind speed.
claim: No wind would have resulted in a safe shot.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Wind X -> Ball in water Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If ball flight physics (Z) show the trajectory without wind lands on green, Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the shot was offline anyway, Invalid.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is VALID. Launch monitor data allows us to strip out the wind vector (X). If the ball's initial velocity and spin would have carried it to the green in still air (X'), then the wind was the but-for cause of the water hazard (Y).
gold_rationale: Physical laws (Z) allow for precise counterfactual simulation. Since the wind vector (X) was sufficient to move the ball from safe to water, removing X restores the safe outcome.

scenario: A coach goes for it on 4th down at midfield (X) and fails. The opponent scores a TD on the short field (Y). Fan says: 'If we punted (X'), they wouldn't have scored.'
claim: Punting would have prevented the touchdown.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Go for it X -> Fail Y. Punt X' -> ?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If punting pins them deep and decreases scoring probability (Z), Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If they score from anywhere, Invalid.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is VALID. Punting (X') would have forced the opponent to drive 80+ yards instead of 50. Statistically, scoring probability decreases significantly with worse field position (Z). The decision to go for it (X) was a necessary condition for the short field.
gold_rationale: While the opponent *could* score from 80 yards, the probability drops drastically. The specific TD (Y) caused by the short field would not have occurred in the counterfactual world of the punt.

scenario: A team misses the playoffs. Fans say: 'If we hadn't paid Player A $50M (X), we could have signed 3 solid starters (X') and made the playoffs (Y).'
claim: Not signing Player A would have led to playoffs.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: If we didn't sign Player A -> We could sign Player B

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If 3 starters were available in free agency (Z), Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the market was empty, Invalid.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. It assumes that (1) 3 solid starters were available (Z) and (2) they would have agreed to sign. If the market was empty, not paying Player A (X) would have just left the team with cap space and no talent.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual relies on the existence of alternative assets (Z). Just having the money (X') does not guarantee the ability to convert it into the specific outcome (Y) without market liquidity.

scenario: Team A wins the OT coin toss (X) and scores a TD to win (Y). Team B claims: 'If we had won the toss (X'), we would have won.'
claim: Winning the coin toss caused the victory.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Win Toss X -> Win Game Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both offenses were dominating (Z), Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it was a defensive struggle, Invalid/Uncertain.

wise_refusal: This is CONDITIONAL. If both offenses were scoring at will against tired defenses (Z), the counterfactual is Validâ€”winning the toss (X) provided the decisive positional advantage. If defenses were holding, the outcome is uncertain.
gold_rationale: Under sudden-death (or TD-win) rules, the coin toss (X) becomes a necessary condition for victory ONLY if the offensive efficiency (Z) approaches 100%.

scenario: Pele scored 1,000 goals in his era (Y). A critic claims: 'If Pele played today against modern defenses (X'), he wouldn't score 1,000 goals.'
claim: Modern defenses would prevent Pele's scoring record.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Era Context Z affects Outcome Y

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Pele transports as-is, Valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Pele also received modern training/nutrition, the gap narrows but likely remains.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual is VALID. Modern defensive organization and fitness (Z) make scoring significantly harder. Even adjusting for Pele receiving modern training, the statistical likelihood of scoring 1,000 goals in the modern game is near zero.
gold_rationale: Structural changes in the game (Z) make the outcome (Y) impossible to replicate in the counterfactual world (X'), regardless of individual talent.

scenario: A wheel comes off (Y) due to a loose nut (X). Team claims: 'If the mechanic tightened the nut (X'), we finish the race.'
claim: Tightening the nut would have ensured finishing.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Loose bolt X -> Crash Y
